tit.e: Wakamizu (the first water drawn from the well on New Year's Day)
Wakamizu (the first water drawn from the well on New Year's Day)

sen.j: 若水（わかみず）とは、元日の早朝に井戸から水を汲んで神棚に供えること。
sen.e: Wakamizu means drawing water from a well early on New Year's Day morning and offering it at a household Shinto altar.

sen.j: また、その汲んだ水のこと。
sen.e: It also means the drawn water.

sen.j: 若水は邪気を除くと信じられ、神棚に供えた後、その水で年神への供物や家族の食事を作ったり、口を漱いだり茶を立てたりした。
sen.e: Being believed to remove bad vibes, wakamizu was used to make an altarage to Toshigami (god of the incoming year), to make a family meal, to rinse out one's mouth and to brew tea after it was offered at a household Shinto altar.

sen.j: 元日の朝早く、まだ人に会わないうちに汲みに行く仕来たりであった。
sen.e: There was a convention to go to draw it early on New Year's Day morning before meeting someone.

sen.j: もし人に会っても口をきかない仕来たりであった。
sen.e: One might not talk to the person if he or she met someone on the way.

sen.j: 若水を汲むのは年男の役目とされたり、その家の女性が汲んだりした。
sen.e: The duty to draw wakamizu was assigned to toshi-otoko (a man born in the year current under the twelve-year cycle of the Orient zodiac), or a woman of the family drew it.

sen.j: 若水を汲む時には「黄金の水を汲みます」など縁起の良い言葉を唱えた。
sen.e: An auspicious phrase, such as "I draw golden water", was chanted on drawing wakamizu.
